headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: Kimmel, Fox and 'Call Me Maybe' Make Waves

docs.abstract: Also, Macy's gets into the high school musical business, and "Fifty Shades of Grey" has fans in the corporate suite.
docs.snippet: Also, Macy's gets into the high school musical business, and "Fifty Shades of Grey" has fans in the corporate suite.

docs.lead_paragraph: During his career, Representative Todd Akin has introduced religion into his work, and on Tuesday, he gave divine reasoning for continuing his run for the Senate.

headline.seo: Akin’s Faith Is Central to His Politics
headline.main: A Politician Whose Faith Is Central to His Persistence
headline.print_headline: A Politician Whose Faith Is Central to His Persistence

docs.abstract: Rep Todd Akin has, throughout his career, introduced religion into his work; under pressure from Republicans to withdraw from Missouri Senate race after his controversial comments about rape and abortion, he gives divine reasoning for continuing his run.
docs.snippet: During his career, Representative Todd Akin has introduced religion into his work, and on Tuesday, he gave divine reasoning for continuing his run for the Senate.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Monica Davey and Steven Yaccino in Chicago, Jonathan Weisman and Rebecca Berg in Washington, and Alain Delaquérière in New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: Why do Republicans have a gender gap when they ascribe superpowers to women, like the ability to block rape sperm with sheer willpower?
docs.abstract: Maureen Dowd Op-Ed column expresses support for Rep Todd Akin's desire to stay in the race for the Senate in Missouri; contends that Akin's comments on rape and abortion merely reflect what he believes, and his stance on abortion rights is shared by many in his party, including Rep Paul Ryan, the vice-presidential candidate.
docs.snippet: Why do Republicans have a gender gap when they ascribe superpowers to women, like the ability to block rape sperm with sheer willpower?

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Todd Akin’s remarks on rape have focused attention on the party’s agenda on restricting abortion rights, a politically volatile topic for Mitt Romney and other candidates.

headline.seo: Akin Controversy Stirs Up Abortion Issue in Campaign
headline.main: Akin Controversy Stirs Up Abortion Issue in Campaign
headline.print_headline: Ignoring Deadline to Quit, G.O.P. Senate Candidate Defies His Party Leaders: Unexpected Twist in the Election Campaigns

docs.abstract: Republican Party's agenda on restricting abortion rights has wedged its way to the center of the 2012 campaign because of Rep Todd Akin's remarks on rape; Akin's record on abortion is largely indistinguishable from his House Republican colleagues, and issue may prove politically volatile for Mitt Romney and other candidates, who would prefer to focus on economic issues.
docs.snippet: Representative Todd Akin’s remarks on rape have focused attention on the party’s agenda on restricting abortion rights, a politically volatile topic for Mitt Romney and other candidates.

byline.contributor: Pam Belluck and Michael Cooper contributed reporting from New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Todd Akin said definitively Tuesday that he would not step aside. After his comments on rape, fellow Republicans, including Mitt Romney, asked him to drop out of the Missouri Senate race.

headline.seo: Akin Refuses to Step Down, Defying Party
headline.main: Ignoring Deadline to Quit, G.O.P. Senate Candidate Defies His Party Leaders
headline.print_headline: Ignoring Deadline to Quit, G.O.P. Senate Candidate Defies His Party Leaders: Akin Digs In and Defends Stand on Abortion

docs.abstract: Rep Todd Akin ignores a deadline to abandon Missouri's Senate race and vows to remain the Republican nominee in defiance of his party's leaders, including Mitt Romney; Romney and other Republicans had called for Akin to step aside after he made controversial comments about rape and abortion.
docs.snippet: Representative Todd Akin said definitively Tuesday that he would not step aside. After his comments on rape, fellow Republicans, including Mitt Romney, asked him to drop out of the Missouri Senate race.

byline.contributor: Monica Davey and Steven Yaccino contributed reporting from Chicago.

headline.main: AMID PROGRESS ON MATERNAL DEATHS, HEARTACHE

docs.abstract: Photo of a Nepalese man being comforted by a relative after his wife died in childbirth; United Nations recently reported that Nepal is one of 10 countries that has reduced the number of women dying of pregnancy and birth-related complications by 75 percent in 20 years. Photo (S)2
